header.title: The Scroll of Set, Issue Number 58, Volume VI-4

central_thesis: This issue of The Scroll of Set serves as an internal dialogue and external declaration clarifying the distinct philosophical and practical identity of the Temple of Set, emphasizing its evolution from the Church of Satan, the core principle of self-directed evolution (Xeper), and the reinterpretation of traditional occult concepts to align with Setian principles of individual will, growth, and challenge to stagnation.

structure_content.summary: This article discusses the Temple of Set's evolution from the Church of Satan, asserting its distinct identity. It critiques Anton LaVey's commercialization of degrees and emphasizes personal growth, self-interest, and the rejection of external validation. It references Michael Aquino's breaking of his pact with LaVey and the passage of the Mandate, highlighting the increasing stringency of Initiate screening and the principle of not accommodating the 'outside world'.

A response to a previous article on terminology, this letter argues that Setians must acknowledge their Satanic roots and confront concepts of 'devils' and 'evil' for personal growth. It emphasizes that the Temple's straightforward approach to its origins enhances initiatory understanding and that softening terminology for external acceptance is counterproductive to Setian evolution.

structure_content.chapter_title: [4] Letter from Stephen H. Bushey III°
structure_content.summary: This letter advocates for the Magician's absolute control over situations and indifference to concepts of 'good' or 'evil' or 'Karmic Law' to avoid guilt and martyrdom. It advises discretion when discussing Setian concepts with the masses and reaffirms the Temple of Set's legitimacy as the successor to the Church of Satan, asserting the continued validity of pre-Xeper terminology and practices for Setian Initiates.

This article clarifies the Setian stance on 'worship' as intense love, admiration, and respect for oneself and one's potential for deification, rejecting subservience. It delves into the historical origins of Set, Satan, and Devil, asserting Set as the original Prince of Darkness and a symbol of opposition to traditions, defiance of death, and the pursuit of knowledge to become a god. It redefines 'evil' from a Setian perspective as 'willing change' and 'eating of the forbidden fruit of knowledge'.

This piece reviews 'The Sacred Magic of Abra=Melin the Mage,' identifying it as a powerful system of 'White Magic' that Setians can learn from. It highlights the importance of concentrated will and emotion in magic, suggesting that lust for a desired goal and rage at a situation can strengthen the will and direct magical operations, even if the underlying philosophy differs from Setian principles.

This report details the re-activation of the Thoth Pylon, focused on reaching the 'Garnet Red' of Adept magic. It presents a Setian reinterpretation of the 'Nine Satanic Statements' from 'The Satanic Bible,' aligning them with Setian principles such as indulgence through creation and change (vs. abstinence), vital existence of real being (vs. spiritual pipe-dreams), undefiled wisdom (vs. self-deceit), selfish kindness, vengeance, integrated self (animal/human), and challenging false 'truths'.

structure_content.chapter_title: [12] Comments on The White People by Arthur Machen
structure_content.summary: This analysis applies a Setian lens to Arthur Machen's 'The White People,' contrasting Machen's 'Light Side' understanding of evil (as unconscious and ascetic) with a Setian perspective. It defines 'sin' as being apart from universal harmony and reinterprets the 'sinner' as one who achieves self-definition through intellectual detachment and manipulation of the natural universe, finding pleasure in assigning relative values to elements for instrumental purposes.

structure_content.chapter_title: [21] The Rite of the Near Sun and the Far Space
structure_content.summary: A ritual text, drawing inspiration from 'Tales From Topographic Oceans,' designed for group participation with alternating passages. The ritual focuses on the themes of change, becoming, and transcending perceived limitations, culminating in the declaration 'Xeper is our means, Xem our goal,' signifying personal evolution and achievement.

This article introduces the Feldenkrais method as a 'new method of Xeper,' demonstrating how bodily exercises can train the nervous system, mind, and spirit. It argues that physical discipline and specific movements lead to enhanced self-awareness and improved functioning, which can be applied to spiritual and magical development, reinforcing the idea that 'practice makes perfect, physically and spiritually'.

key_concepts.definition: The core principle of self-directed evolution, becoming, and self-creation through focused will, emotion, and disciplined practice, culminating in an exalted state of being. 'Xeper is our means, Xem our goal.' It can involve methods like Feldenkraisian body-mind training.

An evolved Satanist, a member of the Temple of Set who is on a path of self-deification, embracing change, individual will, and challenging stagnation. Setians are considered distinct from traditional 'human beings out there' and are characterized by conscious, dedicated study and self-mastery.

A phrase signifying the transformation and progression of the original Church of Satan philosophy into the distinct and more advanced tenets of the Temple of Set, marking a departure from LaVey's commercialization and a deepening of magical practice.

For Setians, this term refers to Set, representing the defiler of stagnation and a force embodying willing change, the pursuit of forbidden knowledge, and the path to becoming a god. It is not an entity to be worshipped in the traditional sense.

Intense love, admiration, and respect directed towards oneself and one's own potential to become a god through maximum use of abilities, rather than a submission of will to an external deity or force. This is distinct from conventional definitions of worship.

As analyzed through Arthur Machen's work, 'sin' is reinterpreted not as an inherently evil act, but as a state of being 'apart from God' (i.e., universal harmony) which is sustained by conscious effort. From a Setian perspective, this implies self-awareness, intellectual detachment from the universal order, and the ability to assign relative values and manipulate elements for one's own instrumental purposes.

The operative side of Setian practice, involving the concentrated application of will and emotion for personal gain and effecting desired changes in one's life and environment. It is a practical method for self-mastery and external influence.
A symbolic term representing the highest point or peak of Adept magic, indicating a significant achievement or level of magical mastery that Setians strive towards.

practical_system.description: The practical system described is centered on individual self-deification through Xeper, a process of personal evolution achieved by conscious will, emotional mastery, and disciplined practice. It involves introspection, challenging conventional norms, and active engagement with the world to effect change. This system integrates insights from traditional magic, emphasizing the power of focused will and emotion, with modern body-mind techniques to foster holistic development—physical, mental, and spiritual. The goal is to maximize one's abilities and realize one's divine potential.
tools: Concentrated will and emotion: Employed as fundamental tools for directing magical operations and achieving desired goals.

Lesser magic: The application of psychological and social manipulation for personal advantage, often used with 'tools of invisibility' to avoid conspicuousness while enacting vengeance or influencing situations.
Greater magic: Broader magical workings and rites aimed at personal evolution and altering reality.
Bodily exercises (Feldenkrais method): Utilized as a 'new method of Xeper' to train the nervous system, mind, and spirit, improving physical, mental, and spiritual self-awareness and performance.

Dedicated study: Engagement with foundational texts like 'The Satanic Bible,' 'Book of Coming Forth By Night,' 'The Sacred Magic of Abra=Melin the Mage,' and the 'Crystal Tablet list' as resources for philosophical and practical knowledge.
rituals: The Rite of the Near Sun and the Far Space: A group ritual focused on change, becoming, and transcending limitations, utilizing evocative language and alternating participation, culminating in the realization of Xeper and Xem.

Regular ritual practice: Implied as a means for spiritual development, facilitating entry into a ritual mood, enhancing concentration, and ensuring smoother execution and greater efficacy of magical operations.

relevant_quotes.text: What precisely this means to each of us must be examined in ourselves on an individual basis. To me it means that while my primary concern is with my self and my growth, I am still not concerned with how those "out there" regard me.
But it may have been this act of mine that ordained his fall ... To make of man a Daimon, then, may be to break his self-reference to the bounds in which his semblance must exist.
The Prince of Darkness exists, I think, as the defiler of stagnation.
We only worship ourselves and our potential to become, through the maximum use of our abilities, gods.

So in the sense of willing change, and being a challenger to all and "eating of the forbidden fruit of knowledge" so as to become a god - to others, from their perspectives, we might be considered "evil".
Xeper is our means, Xem our goal.
Practice makes perfect, physically and spiritually.

critical_analysis.relevance: This collection provides an invaluable insight into the foundational period of the Temple of Set's self-definition, particularly in 1981. It directly addresses the philosophical rupture from LaVeyan Satanism, the establishment of Setian identity, and the practical application of Setian principles like Xeper. The internal debates on terminology and practice reflect a community actively engaged in shaping its unique magical and esoteric system, making it highly relevant for understanding the historical development and core tenets of modern Setianism and its relationship to broader Western Esotericism.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of Initiates and Priesthood members of the Temple of Set (I° through IV°), engaged in personal evolution and magical practice. It also serves academic researchers and practitioners of Western Esotericism and Occultism who seek to understand the technical and philosophical distinctions between LaVeyan Satanism and Setianism, and the practical implementation of Setian concepts like Xeper. The discussions assume a prior understanding of occult terminology and historical context.
